title: How can new authors combat impostor syndrome? - Quora

response.answer_text: People with this problem often had parents who had high standards, gave little praise, but a lot of criticism. They my not have even believed in praise, saying “You should just know when you have done a good job.” The sufferer may also have had a parent or sibling who was superstar—at the top of their field, the golden child, who excelled in everything. The child may have spent their life hearing—”Why can’t you be like your sister or brother? They may have been ignored, no matter their success. Individuals with this syndrome may feel inferior, denigrate their successes, deny victories, refuse to accept praise. Cognitive Restructuring/RET may help. The sufferer needs to ask WHO did the work? Did anyone else do it? Who’s idea was the product or action? Did they steal the work (facetious—but some people may feel they did)? Are all the people praising them fools, suckers, naive? A lucky outcome???—what is luck? Ninety percent perspiration and hard work, 10% being in the right place, with the right idea, and the right skills—-if this is true what does it say about them? Why don’t they DESERVE the success? Are they evil? If evil, why have they not been arrested, exposed, called out? Stupid? If stupid, how were they able to do this? The individual needs to realize that if they came out of a dysfunctional family that produced these feelings—-even now—they are likely to not be recognized, praised, or valued. It is very possible they will hear—Yes but, your brother did_________. Your father was able to__________________. “Big deal, So what, Is that all, Don’t get a swollen head,You are kidding, Who did you pay off, “ and similar phrases may also be heard with a dysfunctional family. You may need to learn to celebrate your successes by yourself and with those who accurately see and know you—valuing what you do.

Stop comparing yourself to other authors, especially the well known ones. Set your expectations accordingly. Fifty Shades of Grey was a fluke, right subject, right time. Harry Potter was a phenomenon, again, right place, right time. And if you want the real story on some famous authors, google how many times their manuscripts were rejected. Your odds of a first novel being a best seller are about the same as winning the lottery. The thing is to have inventory so you don’t fade into obscurity. Publish, even if self published, then have another in the wings to publish a few months later. TLDR: If you’ve completed a novel, you’re an author. If you polish that novel and get it published, you’re then a published author. If you sell one book, count it as a win. If you get one 5 star review from a stranger, count that as a win. Take the little accomplishments as they come, starting with finishing your book. You’d be surprised how many would be writers never even get that much done.
